intro: Dianthus consanguineus, commonly known as the red campion, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is a herbaceous perennial that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring erect stems and basal leaves. The plant produces clusters of small, pink to red flowers with five petals, which bloom in late spring to early summer. Its flowers are characterized by their vibrant color and subtle fragrance, making it a popular choice for gardens. Dianthus consanguineus is also known for its adaptability to various soil types and its ability to thrive in full sun.
